lesson.name: Lesson 2.6: Systems of Linear Equations and Their Solutions

page.title: 2.6.0: Lesson Overview
page.contents:
In this lesson, you will revisit the idea that not all systems of linear equations have a single solution. Next, you will investigate different ways to determine the number of solutions to a system of linear equations.

When you finish this lesson, you will be able to:

  • Determine how many solutions a system of equations could have.

Here are the activities that will help you reach those goals:

  • 2.6.1: Systems of Linear Equations with Infinitely Many Solutions
  • 2.6.2: Systems of Linear Equations with No Solution
  • 2.6.2: Self Check
  • 2.6.3: Sorting Systems of Equations Based on Number of Solutions
  • 2.6.3: Self Check
  • 2.6.4: Writing Consistent and Inconsistent Systems of Equations

After that, you’ll practice and review.

  • 2.6.5: Practice
  • 2.6.6: Lesson Summary

page.title: 2.6.1: Systems of Linear Equations with Infinitely Many Solutions
page.contents:
Warm Up Activity

Andre is trying to solve this system of equations: \( \begin {cases} x + y = 3\\ 4x = 12 - 4y \end{cases} \)

Looking at the first equation, he thought, “The solution to the system is a pair of numbers that add up to 3. I wonder which two numbers they are.”

  1. Choose any two numbers that add up to 3. Let the first one be the \( x \)-value and the second one be the \( y \)-value.

Enter your answer here:

Sample responses: 4 and \(-1\), 0 and 3, \( \frac78 \) and \( 2\frac18 \)


     2. The pair of values you chose is a solution to the first equation. Check if it is also a solution to the second equation. Then, pause for a brief discussion with your group.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer to the sample response:

Yes, it is also a solution to the second equation. Sample reasoning for 4 and -1: Substituting 4 and -1 into the second equation gives \(4(4)=12−4(-1)\) or \(16=12+4\), which is a true equation.


     3. How many solutions does the system have? Use what you know about equations and solving systems to show that you are right.

Enter your answer here:

Check your answer:

Infinitely many solutions

page.title: 2.6.2: Systems of Linear Equations with No Solution
page.contents:
Activity

A recreation center is offering special prices on its pool passes and gym memberships for the summer. On the first day of the offering, a family paid $96 for 4 pool passes and 2 gym memberships. Later that day, an individual bought a pool pass for herself, a pool pass for a friend, and 1 gym membership. She paid $72.

1. Write a system of equations that represents the relationships between pool passes, gym memberships, and the costs. Be sure to state what each variable represents.

Enter your answer here:

\( \begin {cases} \begin {align}4p + 2g &= 96\\2p + 1g &= 72 \end{align} \end{cases} \), where \( p \) is the price of each pool pass and \( g \) is the price of a gym membership for 1 person.


2. Find the price of a pool pass and the price of a gym membership by solving the system algebraically. Explain or show your reasoning.

Enter your answer here:

The system has no solutions. Sample reasoning: Solving by elimination or substitution leads to a false equation (such as \( 0 = 24 \)).


3. Use graphing technology to graph the equations in the system. Make 1–2 observations about your graphs.

Enter your answer here:

 Sample observations: 
  • The graphs are two parallel lines that don’t intersect. 
  • The lines have the same slope but different vertical intercepts.

 


Video: Analyzing Systems of Linear Equations with No Solution 

Watch the following video to learn more about systems that have no solution.

page.title: 2.6.2 Self Check
page.contents:
Solve the system of equations.

\(\left\{\begin{array}{l}-0.1x\;–\;0.2y\;=\;0.6\\–5x\;–\;10y\;=\;1\end{array}\right.\\\)

answer.response: Let’s try again a different way: Multiply the first equation by 50 to get \(-5x - 10y = 30\). Add the equations together. The result is \(0 = 31\). Since this is not true, the answer is no solution.

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Multiply the first equation by 50 to get \(-5x - 10y = 30\). Add the equations together. The result is \(0 = 31\). Since this is not true, the answer is no solution.

answer.answer_text: This system of equations has infinite solutions.
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Multiply the first equation by 50 to get \(-5x - 10y = 30\). Add the equations together. The result is \(0 = 31\). Since this is not true, the answer is no solution

answer.answer_text: This system of equations has no solution.
answer.response: That’s correct! Check yourself: If you multiply the first equation by 50 and add, the result is \(0 = 31\). Since this is not true, the answer is no solution.

answer.answer_text: I am not sure.

page.title: 2.6.2: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Solving an Inconsistent System of Equations

Now that we have several methods for solving systems of equations, we can use the methods to identify inconsistent systems. Recall that an inconsistent system consists of parallel lines that have the same slope but different \( y \)-intercepts. They will never intersect. When searching for a solution to an inconsistent system, we will come up with a false statement, such as \(12 = 0 \).

Solve the following system of equations. 

\( x = 9 - 2y \) 
\( x+2y =13 \) 

Solution 

We can approach this problem in two ways. Because one equation is already solved for \( x \), the most obvious step is to use substitution. 

\( x+2y =13 \) 
\( (9-2y)+2y =13 \) 
\( 9+0y =13 \) 
\( 9=13  \) 

Clearly, this statement is a contradiction because \( 9 \neq 13 \). Therefore, the system has no solution. 

The second approach would be to first manipulate the equations so that they are both in slope-intercept form. We manipulate the first equation as follows:

\( x = 9 - 2y \)
\( 2y = -x + 9x\)
\( y= -\frac{1}{2}x + \frac{9}{2} \)

We then convert the second equation expressed to slope-intercept form. 

\( x + 2y = 13 \)
\( 2y = -x + 13\)
\( y= -\frac{1}{2}x + \frac{13}{2} \)

Comparing the equations, we see that they have the same slope but different \(y\)-intercepts. Therefore, the lines are parallel and do not intersect. 

\( y= \frac{1}{2}x + \frac{9}{2} \)
\( y= -\frac{1}{2}x + \frac{13}{2} \)

Try It: Solving an Inconsistent System of Equations

Solve the following system of equations. If there is no solution, explain how you know.

\( 9x +3y = -24 \)
\( 6x +2y = 14 \)

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Here is how to solve the system:

To solve using elimination, we must first make the coefficients of one of the variables the same to use subtraction.

\( 2(9x +3y) = 2(-24) \)
\( 3(6x +2y) = 3(14) \)

After simplifying, we have:

\( 18x +6y = -48 \)
\( 18x +6y = 42 \)

Let’s subtract the equations:

\( 18x +6y = -48 \)
\( 18x +6y = 42 \)
\( 0 = -90 \)

Since this equation can never be true, the system has no solutions.

Using another method, you can also write each equation in slope-intercept form:

\( y = -3x - 8 \)
\( y = -3x - 7 \)

Since the equations have the same slope and different \(y\)-intercepts, we know that the system has no solution.

How did you do? Know that you learn more from wrong answers than from right answers. Wrong answers help us find flaws in our thinking. Take a minute to think about why you got the question wrong. Then you won’t get this type of question wrong again!>

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I'm ready for the next activity.

page.title: 2.6.3: Sorting Systems of Equations Based on Number of Solutions
page.contents:
Activity

Your teacher will give you a set of cards. Each card contains a system of equations.


Sort the systems into three groups based on the number of solutions each system has. Be prepared to explain how you know where each system belongs.


Enter your answer here:

Check your answers:

  • No solution: Cards 2 and 5
  • One solution: Cards 1, 4, 6, and 9
  • Infinitely many solutions: Cards 3, 7, and 8

1. In the cards for each system with no solution, change a single constant term so that there are infinitely many solutions to the system.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

Card 2: change 3 to 13; Card 5: change \(-12\) to 12.


2. For each system with infinitely many solutions, change a single constant term so that there are no solutions to the system.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

Any change to a constant term would work.


3. Explain why in these situations it is impossible to change a single constant term so that there is exactly one solution to the system.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

Changing a constant term won’t change the slope of the lines, so the graphs will be either distinct parallel lines or the same line.

page.title: 2.6.3: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Classifying and Rewriting Systems of Equations

Find a solution to the system of equations using the addition method.

\(\begin{array}{rcl}x+3y&=&2\\3x+9y&=&6\end{array}\)

Solution

With the addition method, we want to eliminate one of the variables by adding the equations. In this case, let’s focus on eliminating x. If we multiply both sides of the first equation by −3 then we will be able to eliminate the x-variable.

\(x+3y=2\)
\((-3)(x+3y)=(-3)(2)\)
\(-3x-9y=-6\)

Now add the equations.

\(\begin{array}{r}-3x-9y=-6\\+3x+9y=6\\\hline0=0\end{array}\)

We can see that there will be an infinite number of solutions that satisfy both equations.


Try It: Classifying and Rewriting Systems of Equations

Change a single constant term in the system from above so that there are no solutions.

\(x + 3y = 2\)

\(3x + 9y = 6\)

Show that you were successful in changing the system to have no solution.

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Here is how to rewrite the system so there is no solution:

We can simply change the 2 in the first equation to any other number, such as 5.

\(x + 3y = 5\)

\(3x + 9y = 6\)

Let’s try to prove there is no solution. Using substitution:

\(x + 3y = 5\)

\(x = 5 - 3y\)

Substitute this expression into the second equation.

\(3x + 9y = 6\)

\(3(5 - 3y) + 9y = 6\)

\(15 - 9y + 9y = 6\)

\(15 ≠ 6\)

Since the equation is not true, then the system has no solution.

How did you do? Know that you learn more from wrong answers than from right answers. Wrong answers help us find flaws in our thinking. Take a minute to think about why you got the question wrong. Then you won’t get this type of question wrong again!

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 2.6.4: Writing Consistent and Inconsistent Systems of Equations
page.contents:
Cool Down Activity

Here is an equation: \(5x - 2y = 10\).

Create a second equation that would make a system of equations with:

  1. One solution
  2. No solutions
  3. Infinitely many solutions

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answers:

  1.  \(3x - y = 7\)
  2.  \(5x - 2y = 20\)
  3.  \(15x - 6y = 30\)

page.title: 2.6.3: Self Check
page.contents:
Which of the following is true of the following system of equations?

\(\begin{array}{rcl}&&\left\{\begin{array}{l}7x\;+\;6y\;=\;2\\–28x\;–\;24y\;=\;–8\end{array}\right.\end{array}\)

answer.answer_text: The system of equations has no solutions.
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Did you write both equations in slope-intercept form? The answer is that both equations have the same slope when written in slope-intercept form.

answer.answer_text: The system of equations has exactly one solution.
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Did you write both equations in slope-intercept form? The answer is that both equations have the same slope when written in slope-intercept form.

answer.answer_text: If you write both equations in slope-intercept form, they have different \(y\)-intercepts.
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Did you write both equations in slope-intercept form? The equations have the same \(y\)-intercept. The answer is that both equations have the same slope when written in slope-intercept form.

answer.answer_text: If you write both equations in slope-intercept form, they have the same slope.
answer.response: That’s correct! Check yourself: These equations have the same slope and represent the same line.

answer.answer_text: I am not sure.

page.title: 2.6.5: Practice
page.contents:
Complete the following questions to practice the skills you have learned in this lesson.

For questions 1–8, solve each system of equations to determine if there is one solution, no solution, or infinitely many solutions.


1. \( \begin {cases} 5x − 3y = 7\\ x − 0.6y = 1.4 \end{cases} \)

Correct! infinitely many solutions

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 2.6.1. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is infinitely many solutions. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

2. \( \begin {cases} −x+2y=−1\\ 5x−10y=6 \end{cases} \)

Correct! no solution

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 2.6.2 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is no solution. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

3. \( \begin {cases} 7x+6y=2\\ −28x−24y=−8 \end{cases} \)

Correct! infinitely many solutions

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 2.6.1. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is infinitely many solutions. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

4. \( \begin {cases} −0.2x + 0.4y = 0.6\\ x−2y=−3 \end{cases} \)

Correct! infinitely many solutions

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 2.6.1 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is infinitely many solutions. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

5. \( \begin {cases} −0.1x + 0.2y = 0.6\\ 5x−10y=1 \end{cases} \)

Correct! no solution

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 2.6.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is no solution. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

6. \( \begin {cases} 3x+6y=11\\ 2x+4y=9 \end{cases} \)

Correct! no solution

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 2.6.2 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is no solution. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

7. \( \begin {cases} −x+2y=4\\ 2x−4y=1 \end{cases} \)

Correct! no solution

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 2.6.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is no solution. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

8. \( \begin {cases} 3x−2y=5\\ −9x+6y=−15 \end{cases} \)

Correct! infinitely many solutions

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 2.6.1 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is infinitely many solutions. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

9. Which system of equations has infinitely many solutions?

Correct! \(4x + 3y = 12\) and \(8x + 6y = 24\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 2.6.3 and 2.6.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \(4x + 3y = 12\) and \(8x + 6y = 24\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

10. Which system of equations has no solution?

Multiple choice:

Correct! \(3x + 7y = 15\) and \(3x + 7y = 40\)

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activities 2.6.3 and 2.6.4 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \(3x + 7y = 15\) and \(3x + 7y = 40\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

page.title: 2.6.6: Lesson Summary
page.contents:
In this lesson, you learned how to:

  • Determine how many solutions a system of equations could have.

Here are the activities that helped you reach those goals:

  • 2.6.1: Systems of Linear Equations with Infinitely Many Solutions
    • In this activity, you analyzed a system of equations that has infinitely many solutions. When solving by graphing, the graphs of the equations are the same line. When solving by substitution or elimination, you end up with an equation, such as \(4x = 4x\), that is always true no matter what value is used.
  • 2.6.2: Systems of Linear Equations with No Solution
    • In this activity, you analyzed a system of equations that has no solution. This means there are no values that make both equations in the system true. When solving by graphing, the graphs of the equations are parallel lines that never intersect. When solving by substitution or elimination, you end up with an equation, such as \(0 = 24\), that is never true.
  • 2.6.2: Self Check
  • 2.6.3: Sorting Systems of Equations Based on Number of Solutions
    • In this activity, you solved many different systems of equations in order to sort which systems had one solution, infinitely many solutions, or no solution.
  • 2.6.3: Self Check 
  • 2.6.4: Writing Consistent and Inconsistent Systems of Equations
    • In this activity, you wrote new systems of equations to have one solution, infinitely many solutions, or no solution. By writing new systems of equations from each category, you demonstrated an awareness of the characteristics of each type of system.

After these activities, you completed the following practice:

  • 2.6.5: Practice

Checking In

On a scale of 1 to 5, how confident do you feel about the learning goals of this lesson?

Correct!

If you’ve answered 3 or less, be sure to reach out to your teacher before starting the next lesson.
